sections.text:
Jackiw-Teitelboim Gravity from the Karch-Randall Braneworld
Hao Geng ,1 Andreas Karch ,2 Carlos Perez-Pardavila ,2 Suvrat Raju ,3
Lisa Randall ,1 Marcos Riojas,2 and Sanjit Shashi 2 1Center for the Fundamental Laws of Nature, Harvard University,
17 Oxford Street, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02139, USA 2Theory Group, Department of Physics, University of Texas, Austin, Texas 78712, USA 3International Centre for Theoretical Sciences, Tata Institute of Fundamental Research,
Shivakote, Bengaluru 560089, India
(Received 4 July 2022; accepted 20 October 2022; published 29 November 2022)
In this Letter, we show that Jackiw-Teitelboim gravity can be naturally realized in the Karch-Randall braneworld. Notably the role of the dilaton in Jackiw-Teitelboim gravity is played by the radion in a suitably orbifolded version of the setup. In the classical entanglement entropy calculation, there is an apparent degeneracy of Ryu-Takayanagi surfaces. We demonstrate how quantum fluctuations of the radion/ dilaton resolve this would-be classical puzzle regarding entanglement wedge reconstruction.
DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevLett.129.231601
Introduction.—Recent use of the doubly holographic Karch-Randall braneworld [1,2] has yielded substantial insights into quantum gravity. These include analytical models that have been used to produce Page curves describing black hole radiation in higher-dimensional (i.e., in d > 2 spacetime dimensions) setups [3,4,5], demonstrating a connection between the existence of entanglement islands and massive gravity theories [4,10,11], providing simple holographic models to study quantum field theory in black hole backgrounds [12,13], and motivating a novel holographic setup: wedge holography [10,11,14,15]. Wedge holography is a simple canonical deformation of the original Karch-Randall braneworld that manifests a codimension-two holographic duality [10,11,14,15]. This setup starts with two AdSd (AdS, anti–de Sitter) KarchRandall branes in an ambient AdSdþ1 with the two branes intersecting each other at the conformal boundary of the ambient spacetime. These branes are treated as “end-of-theworld” (EOW) branes, meaning that the part of the ambient spacetime behind them is excised. Thus, the leftover bulk spacetime is a wedge [see Fig. 1(a)]. In analogy with the original Karch-Randall braneworld, the wedge system is doubly holographic in that there are three equivalent descriptions related to each other by the AdS=CFT correspondence [16–18] (see Fig. 1): (i) bulk description, Einstein-Hilbert gravity in the wedge; (ii) intermediate
description, two CFTd’s (CFT, conformal field theory) coupled with gravity living on separate AdSd’s and glued to each other along their asymptotic boundaries by imposing transparent boundary conditions; (iii) boundary description, a CFTd−1 living on the common asymptotic boundary of the two branes [which is the corner of the wedge in Fig. 1(a)]. In this Letter, we study wedge holography when the bulk is AdS3 with two AdS2 branes. As opposed to the original wedge holography setup in higher dimensions where the brane fluctuations can be neglected, we will consider fluctuating branes with orbifold projection so that there is only one fluctuating scalar degree of freedom. This scalar is the “radion” in the language of the Randall-Sundrum I setup [19]. We will derive an action for the radion that is coupled with the 2d localized braneworld gravity. This can be thought of as the low-energy effective theory of the intermediate description. We will see that this theory is

0031-9007=22=129(23)=231601(5) 231601-1 Published by the American Physical Society
precisely the Jackiw-Teitelboim (JT) gravity [20–22], in which the dilaton field is the radion. The importance of our study is that it ensures the consistency of wedge holography in AdS3. This is because when we ignore the brane fluctuations and study the entanglement entropy in AdS3 wedge holography using the Ryu-Takayanagi (RT) formula, we find an infinite number of degenerate RT surfaces. This renders the entanglement wedge, which is an essential element in holography [23], as undefined. Taking into account the brane fluctuations, this degeneracy is lifted, as we show explicitly using our effective JT description. We note that JT gravity [24–28] has also played an important role in the recent development of lowdimensional (d ¼ 2) quantum gravity [6,7,29]. This includes providing an analytically controllable model to compute the Page curve of evaporating black holes [6,7] and a precise duality between Euclidean JT gravity to a random matrix ensemble [29]. Our realization of JT gravity in the Karch-Randall braneworld further argues for its significance in our study of quantum gravity [30]. Karch-Randall braneworld and wedge holography.—In this section, we briefly review the Karch-Randall braneworld and wedge holography, focusing on the geometric pictures for later holographic study. The original theory of Karch and Randall is described by the following action:
S ¼ − 1 16πGdþ1
Z ddþ1x ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi −gbulk p ðR½gbulk − 2ΛÞ
− 1
8πGdþ1
Z ddx ffiffiffiffiffiffi −h p ðK − TÞ; ð1Þ
where the first term is the standard Einstein-Hilbert action describing gravity in the ambient AdSdþ1 with a cosmological constant Λ ¼ −½dðd − 1Þ=2 (we have set the AdS curvature length to 1), the second term describes the embedding of the brane in the ambient AdSdþ1, hab is the induced metric on the brane, K is the trace of the extrinsic curvature of the brane, and T is the tension of the brane and satisfies T ≤ ðd − 1Þ as a Karch-Randall brane. (The critical value T ¼ d − 1 corresponds to the RandallSundrum brane [19,31].) The bulk metric fluctuations satisfy the Neumann boundary condition near the brane
∇nδgbulk μνjnear brane ¼ 0; ð2Þ where n denotes the normal direction of the brane. With this boundary condition taken into account, setting the variation of the action Eq. (1) to zero we obtain two equations of motion: the usual Einstein’s field equation that determines the bulk geometry and the brane-localized equation of motion describing the embedding of the brane in the bulk. The latter is given by [32]
Kab ¼ ðK − TÞhab: ð3Þ
This system of equations can be solved by
ds2bulk ¼ dr2 þ cosh2ðrÞds2AdSd ; ð4Þ
where r ∈ ð−∞;∞Þ, with the brane given by r ¼ r1 ¼ const: and T ¼ ðd − 1Þj tanh r1j (we only consider positive tension branes) [33]. The bulk metric is just empty AdSdþ1 written as a foliation into AdSd slices. This is particularly useful in the study of the Karch-Randall braneworld as here the brane geometry r ¼ const: is clearly AdSd. In this Letter, we focus on the case d ¼ 2, in which case the geometry can be easily visualized as that on the left of Fig. 2(a). In the wedge holography setup [10,11,14,15], we add another (positive tension) Karch-Randall brane. This system is described by the following action:
S ¼ − 1 16πG3
Z d3x ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi −gbulk p ðR½gbulk − 2ΛÞ
− 1
8πG3 Z i¼1;2 ddx ffiffiffiffiffiffiffi −hi p ðKi − TiÞ; ð5Þ
where we impose the Neumann boundary conditions [Eq. (2)] for the bulk metric fluctuation near both branes. The equations of motion still consist of two parts: the bulk Einstein’s equation and the two brane-localized equations, with each one the same as Eq. (3) but with their own tensions T1 and T2. Hence, a solution is given by the same bulk metric [Eq. (4)] with d ¼ 2, where r ∈ ðr1; r2Þ, T1 ¼ tanhð−r1Þ, T2 ¼ tanh r2, r1 < 0, and r2 > 0. This geometry is visualized in Fig. 2(b). Realizing JT gravity.—In the original wedge holography papers [10,11,14,15] the branes are treated as rigid. This assumption is rooted in the original Karch-Randall setup where we just have one brane and we can take the brane to be sitting at an orbifold fixed point to model an EOW brane in analog to O-planes in string theory [35,36]. However,
231601-2
reminding ourselves of the Randall-Sundrum I setup [19] with two Randall-Sundrum branes, the relative distance between the branes is a dynamical variable called the “radion,” which has important phenomenological implications [37]. Hence, in the case of wedge holography, we should not neglect the possibility of brane fluctuations. In this section, we consider small brane fluctuations (relative to the bulk AdS3 curvature scale) and derive the effective action for the coupling between these small fluctuations and the brane-localized graviton mode by doing dimensional reduction. While brane fluctuations can be neglected in higher dimensions, we will see that this small contribution plays an important role when the bulk is AdS3. The detailed derivation and a more careful analysis will be presented in [30]. To be precise, we will consider two branes with tensions T1 and T2 sitting at r ¼ r1 þ δϕ1ðxÞ and r ¼ r2 þ δϕ2ðxÞ slices of the following bulk geometry:
ds2 ¼ dr2 þ cosh2ðrÞgabðxÞdxadxb; ð6Þ
with the relationships T1 ¼ − tanh r1 > 0 and T2 ¼ tanh r2 > 0 satisfied and δϕ1; δϕ2 ≪ 1 (the AdS length scale has been set to 1). The wedge runs from r ¼ r1 þ δϕ1ðxÞ to r ¼ r2 þ δϕ2ðxÞ, and the metric ansatz [Eq. (6)] describes the lowest 2d graviton mode [the higher modes would depend on the coordinate r as gabðr; xÞ]. To obtain the low-energy effective action, we have to plug the above ansatz of the metric and brane locations into Eq. (5) and keep terms only up to orderOðδϕ2Þ. This yields the following action (for details of the derivation, we refer readers to [30]):
Seff ¼ S0 − 1
16πG3
Z d2x ffiffiffiffiffiffi −g p ϕðxÞ½R½g þ 2 þ Sdilaton;
ð7Þ
where ϕðxÞ ¼ δϕ2ðxÞ − δϕ1ðxÞ is the radion mode, S0 is a purely topological term,
S0 ¼ − r2 − r1 16πG3
Z d2x ffiffiffiffiffiffi −g p R½g ; ð8Þ
and Sdilaton is the kinetic term for the brane fluctuations
Sdilaton ¼ − 1
8πG3
Z d2x ffiffiffiffiffiffi −g
p T2 2 ∇μδϕ2∇μδϕ2 þ T2ðδϕ2Þ2
þ T1 2 ∇μδϕ1∇μδϕ1 þ T1ðδϕ1Þ2 : ð9Þ
In analogy to the Randall-Sundrum scenario, to isolate the dynamics of the radion we have to orbifold our setup. We can project out either δϕ1ðxÞ or δϕ2ðxÞ by a canonical orbifold prescription: start with an array of an infinite number of paired wedges, mod out the translation
symmetry on the array to a single pair of wedges with Z2 symmetry, and then mod out this Z2 symmetry (see Ref. [30] for details) to get a single wedge with only one fluctuating brane. The possibility of projecting out either δϕ1ðxÞ or δϕ2ðxÞ is gauge-equivalent. To see this gauge equivalence, without loss of generality we can project out δϕ1ðxÞ and redefine gabðxÞ such that the final action is independent of r1 and r2. Specifically, by setting
δϕ1ðxÞ ¼ 0; gabðxÞ → e−T2δϕ2ðxÞgabðxÞ; ð10Þ
the total action becomes
Seff ¼ S0 − 1
16πG3
Z d2x ffiffiffiffiffiffi −g p ϕðxÞ½R½g þ 2 ; ð11Þ
where now the dilaton field is ϕðxÞ ¼ δϕ2ðxÞ. This is precisely Jackiw-Teitelboim gravity [20,21] for AdS2. However, there is no nontrivial profile for the dilaton on the AdS2 background without a cutoff [38]. This cutoff breaks the asymptotic conformal symmetry and allows the theory to have finite energy excitations [26]. Hence, we fix a small cutoff ϵ and fix the boundary metric for the nearly AdS2 and the dilaton field to be
gabðxÞjbdydxadxb¼− du2
ϵ2 ; ϕðxÞjbdy¼ϕb¼ ϕr ϵ : ð12Þ
One subtlety of our derivation is that we have to take ϕb ∼ ϵ (or ϕr ∼ ϵ2) to ensure that the brane fluctuation is always small, i.e., δϕiðxÞ ≪ 1. We emphasize that this scaling is special to our setup. For example, it does not appear in dimensional reduction for the near-horizon region of a fourdimensional near-extremal black holes [39,40]. In that case ϕb is determined by the linear-in-temperature coefficient of the near-extremal black hole entropy [28]. In our case, without an UV completion of the underlying higherdimensional theory, ϕb is a free parameter. (We thank Subir Sachdev for useful discussions regarding this interesting point.) In our case, the UV completion is a conformal quantum mechanics system [30], which differs from the UV completion into a black hole. Translating to the AdS3 language [Eq. (6)], we have to take a cutoff of the AdS3 wedge and fix the metric there to be (see Fig. 3 for an indication)
ds2bdy ¼ dr2 − cosh2ðrÞ du2
ϵ2 : ð13Þ
Now that we have identified this cutoff and boundary conditions for the metric in the AdS3 bulk, we have to add the corresponding boundary term to the total action [Eq. (5)]. The boundary term is the usual GibbonsHawking (GH) term

Z d2xbdy ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi −hbdy p Kð3Þ; ð14Þ
which can be shown to be
Sbdy¼− 2ðr2−r1Þ 16πG3 Z ∂M dx ffiffiffiffiffiffi −h p K− 2ϕb 16πG3 Z ∂M dx ffiffiffiffiffiffi −h p K;
ð15Þ
where K is the trace of the extrinsic curvature of the cutoff boundary of the AdS2. With this term added to Eq. (11), we get the full-fledged JT gravity action as that in [41]. We refer readers to [30] for more details. A puzzle and its resolution.—A canonical quantity to study in AdS3 wedge holography is the entanglement entropy between the two asymptotic defects that support the dual quantum mechanics [see Fig. 2(b)]. This can be calculated using the Ryu-Takayanagi (RT) formula [42,43] by studying the RT surfaces that connect the two branes [10,14]. Choosing global AdS2 for those AdS2 slices, the bulk metric [Eq. (4)] can be written as
ds2 ¼ dr2 þ cosh2ðrÞ½−cosh2ðηÞdτ2 þ dη2 ; ð16Þ
if we ignore the brane fluctuations δϕiðxÞ. The RT surface can be parametrized as η ¼ ηðrÞ, τ ¼ const:, which leads to the area functional
A ¼ Z r2
r1
dr ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi 1þ cosh2ðrÞη0ðrÞ2 q : ð17Þ
It is easy to show that, with the boundary term carefully taken into account, the variation of the area functional vanishes if and only if η0ðrÞ ¼ 0. Therefore, any constant η surface is an RT surface and they all have equal area A ¼ r2 − r1 (see Fig. 4 for an illustration). According to this result, there would be no definite RT surface for the entanglement entropy between the two defects and as a
corollary there would be no definite entanglement wedge for either of the defects. This would be problematic because it would preclude a holographic interpretation from the point of view of bulk (or more precisely, entanglement wedge [44]) reconstruction. Fortunately, this puzzling result occurs only when the branes are treated as rigid. We expect brane fluctuations to lift the degeneracy of the RT surfaces. Because the brane fluctuation is in general time-dependent, we should use the Hubeny-Rangamani-Takayanagi (HRT) formula [45] to compute the entanglement entropy from the wedge. However, this would be complicated as the result is heavily dependent on properly treating the boundary condition near the brane. This challenge of computing entanglement entropy with brane fluctuations is readily met if we instead do it using our effective braneworld theory [Eq. (11)]. In that case we are just computing the entanglement entropy between the two cutoff boundaries of the nearly AdS2 space. By solving the equation of motion of the dilaton and 2d metric, we have that
ds22d ¼ −cosh2ðηÞdτ2 þ dη2; ð18Þ
ϕðxÞ ¼ ϕr cosh η cos τ; ð19Þ
where ϕr is a constant. Thus, using the maxmin prescription [46] of the HRT formula, we have
SEE ¼ max τ min η
ϕ0 þ ϕðxÞ
4G3
¼ ϕ0 þ ϕr
4G3 ; ð20Þ
where the minimization has a solution η ¼ 0, τ ¼ 0. As a result, from the bulk AdS3 perspective [Eq. (16)], the RT surface is just the η ¼ 0 surface that sits precisely in the middle of the bulk (i.e., the middle green surface in Fig. 4). Thus, the entanglement wedge of either defect is the half bulk region next to it, which is consistent with the symmetry between the two defects.
231601-4
Conclusions.—In this Letter, we studied wedge holography when the bulk is three-dimensional. We found that it is necessary to consider brane fluctuations, identified as the radion mode in the braneworld language [19,31], for the apparent consistency of the holographic setup. We found that the low-energy dynamics of the brane fluctuations with orbifold projection is precisely Jackiw-Teitelboim gravity.

title: Jackiw-Teitelboim Gravity from the Karch-Randall Braneworld
